population_specificity: A 49-year-old pastor with chronic pain affecting multiple sites and associated symptoms (tachycardia, shortness of breath, gastrointestinal complaints).
effective_dosage: 5% dextrose administered three times at monthly intervals.
study_duration: Three months (with follow-up at nine months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the incidence of hypoglycemia in hospitalized patients with renal disease treated with insulin and dextrose for hyperkalemia and evaluate the impact of guideline changes, including the use of sodium zirconium cyclosilicate (SZC).
results_summary: The study found that the introduction of SZC and changes in patient care, including hourly glucose monitoring, led to a 73% reduction in iatrogenic hypoglycemia and more appropriate use of insulin/dextrose.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with renal disease and hyperkalemia.
study_duration: Up to 6 hours of monitoring post-administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of hypertonic dextrose proliferation therapy in treating rotator cuff injuries by comparing it to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found that hypertonic dextrose therapy significantly improved VAS scores, SPADI scores, flexion, and abduction in patients with rotator cuff injuries, though internal and external rotation improvements were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Individuals with rotator cuff lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of 5 g boluses of 10%, 25%, and 50% dextrose in treating hypoglycemic patients with altered mental status.
results_summary: The study found no difference in the median time to achieve a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 15 among the three dextrose concentrations (6 minutes). However, the 50% dextrose group required higher total median doses (15 g) compared to the 10% and 25% groups (10 g).
population_specificity: Hypoglycemic patients with altered mental status presenting to an emergency department.
effective_dosage: 5 g boluses of 10%, 25%, or 50% dextrose administered intravenously over 1 minute.
study_duration: Single administration during the emergency visit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dextrose and autologous blood injection as prolotherapy agents in treating chronic recurrent TMJ dislocation.
results_summary: Dextrose was effective in reducing pain and joint hypermobility within a week, but autologous blood injection was more efficient in reducing mouth opening and limiting TMJ dislocations at 6-month and annual follow-ups.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic recurrent TMJ dislocation (n=16 in the dextrose group).
study_duration: Rehabilitation initiated three weeks post-treatment, with follow-ups up to one year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain-relief efficacy of oral dextrose, acetaminophen, and placebo during retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) examinations in premature infants.
results_summary: Dextrose showed no significant difference in pain reduction compared to placebo or acetaminophen during ROP examinations, with a mean PIPP-R score of 12.17 (vs. 11.54 for placebo and 11.39 for acetaminophen). The difference between groups was not statistically significant (P = 0.38).
population_specificity: Premature neonates with birth weight ≤2000 g and gestational age between 28 and 34 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hospital-based 40% dextrose gel (DG) in preventing and treating asymptomatic hypoglycemia in infants of diabetic mothers (IDM), large for gestational age (LGA), and macrosomic neonates.
results_summary: The study found that implementing 40% dextrose gel significantly reduced the need for intravenous dextrose administration (3.4% vs. 10.3%, p < 0.001) but did not significantly affect the incidence of hypoglycemia or length of hospital stay.
population_specificity: Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM), large for gestational age (LGA), and macrosomic neonates.
effective_dosage: 40% dextrose gel applied within 30-45 min after birth, with up to three additional doses in the first 6 hours of life.
study_duration: Intervention administered during the first 6 hours of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of intrauterine dextrose infusion on metabolic status, systemic inflammation, milk yield, and rumination time in dairy cows with high vaginal discharge scores (VDS4 and VDS5).
results_summary: Dextrose treatment showed mixed efficacy—it restored milk yield in cows with VDS4 to levels comparable to healthy cows but reduced milk yield in cows with VDS5 compared to conventional treatment. No significant differences in systemic inflammation (haptoglobin levels) were observed between dextrose and conventional treatment groups.
population_specificity: Holstein dairy cows with vaginal discharge scores 4 or 5 in early lactation (7±3 days in milk).
effective_dosage: Three intrauterine infusions of 50% dextrose solution (1 L/cow) every 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dextrose prolotherapy (DP) with autologous conditioned serum (ACS) in treating patients with TMJ internal derangement (ID).
results_summary: Dextrose prolotherapy (DP) was less effective than ACS in reducing pain, improving mouth opening, and correcting jaw deviation in TMJ ID patients. The study found statistically significant improvements in the ACS group but did not highlight DP's efficacy as strongly.
population_specificity: 24 participants with TMJ internal derangement (Wilkes II-V).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare serum chloride levels and the incidence of dyselectrolytemia, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis (HCMA), acute kidney injury (AKI), and mortality in children receiving 5% Dextrose in Ringer's Lactate (RLD5) versus 5% Dextrose Normal Saline (DNS).
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant but clinically insignificant difference in serum chloride levels between the two groups. The incidence of AKI and HCMA was low in both groups, with no mortality reported.
population_specificity: Non-critically ill children aged 6 months to 14 years requiring intravenous fluids.
effective_dosage: 5% Dextrose in Ringer's Lactate (RLD5) or 5% Dextrose Normal Saline (DNS).
study_duration: Outcomes were analyzed at 24 and 48 hours after starting the maintenance IV fluid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the cause of false-positive serum Aspergillus antigen galactomannan (GM) results, specifically investigating the role of dextrose-containing fluids.
results_summary: The study found that dextrose-containing fluids administered within 6 days before GM testing were a significant independent predictor of false-positive GM results, with 34.8% and 33.3% of samples from two manufacturers testing positive. Restricting the use of these fluids led to a significant reduction in false-positive results.
population_specificity: 568 patients tested for serum Aspergillus antigen GM, including 97 with false-positive results (cases) and 427 with true-negative results (controls).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the effects of porcine intestinal mucosal peptides (PIMP) on inflammation and colitis, not Dextrose.
results_summary: The study found that PIMP controlled inflammatory responses in vitro and alleviated intestinal inflammation in mice, improving barrier function and gut microbiota.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cell model and DSS-induced colitis in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of prolotherapy (using dextrose) on functional measures and quality of life in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in self-reported functioning and pain scores at one-, two-, and three-month follow-ups, but no significant changes in quality-of-life (EQ5D) or stiffness (WOMAC) scores.
population_specificity: 15 male and female patients aged 50-85 with knee osteoarthritis and moderate pain.
study_duration: 3 months (with follow-ups at one, two, and three months post-procedure)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of oral dextrose gel in preventing hypoglycemia and reducing long-term neurodevelopmental impairment in newborn infants at risk of hypoglycemia.
results_summary: Oral dextrose gel reduces the risk of neonatal hypoglycemia and probably reduces the need for treatment without adverse effects, but it may have little to no impact on major neurological disability at two years.
population_specificity: Newborn infants at risk of hypoglycemia, including infants of diabetic mothers, high or low birthweight, and preterm infants (<37 weeks), aged from birth to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of hypertonic dextrose prolotherapy (HDP) with conventional physiotherapy (CPT) in improving symptoms in females with knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: HDP showed significantly greater improvements in pain, functionality, and strength compared to CPT at 1 and 3 months post-treatment, with statistically significant improvements in all outcome parameters. Both treatments were effective, but HDP yielded superior results.
population_specificity: 60 female patients diagnosed with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 25% dextrose injection into the knee joint and 15% dextrose around the knee, administered in two sessions over 1 month.
study_duration: 1 month (with follow-up at 1 and 3 months post-treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of intravenous hypertonic dextrose solution versus oral gluconeogenic precursors with nicotinamide in treating subclinical ketosis in Chilika buffaloes.
results_summary: Intravenous dextrose significantly increased blood glucose levels by day 7 and was more effective than oral gluconeogenic precursors in restoring recovery from subclinical ketosis. Liver function indicators improved in both treatment groups.
population_specificity: Lactating Chilika buffaloes with subclinical ketosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (hypertonic dextrose solution administered intravenously).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of enteral free water versus parenteral dextrose 5% in water (D5W) for treating ICU-acquired hypernatremia.
results_summary: Parenteral D5W was slightly more effective than enteral free water in lowering serum sodium levels, with no significant differences in secondary outcomes like complications or mortality. Both treatments were effective for hypernatremia.
population_specificity: Adult ICU patients with ICU-acquired hypernatremia (Na ≥ 145 mEq/L) in a mixed medical-surgical ICU in Japan.
effective_dosage: Median daily treatment volume of 799 mL (IQR 299-1221 mL) for D5W.
study_duration: Median treatment duration of 6 days (range 3-17 days) for D5W.
interactions: Hydrochlorothiazide was associated with a statistically significant negative effect on serum sodium levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the stability of SB12 (a biosimilar to eculizumab) when diluted in 5% dextrose under extended storage conditions not claimed in the originator label.
results_summary: SB12 diluted in 5% dextrose showed instability in charge variants, while other stability parameters (physicochemical properties, biological activity, and subvisible particles) were maintained. This suggests dextrose may not be an ideal diluent for SB12 under the tested conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
study_duration: Up to 3 months at 5 ± 3 °C, then 72 h at 30 ± 2 °C/65 ± 5% RH

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of combined intra and extraarticular dextrose prolotherapy versus intra-articular triamcinolone injection in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both dextrose prolotherapy and triamcinolone significantly improved pain and function in knee osteoarthritis patients. Dextrose showed less short-term pain reduction but more persistent and greater midterm (3 months) effectiveness compared to triamcinolone.
population_specificity: 50 patients suffering from knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Intra-articular injection of 10cc dextrose 16% and periarticular intradermal injections of dextrose 12% (2.5 cc at each of 4 points around the knee).
study_duration: One session, with follow-up at 1 and 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of prolotherapy using different dextrose concentrations (5%, 10%, and 20%) in treating knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Higher dextrose concentrations (10% and 20%) showed significant improvements in pain and function compared to the control group, with 20% dextrose demonstrating the most consistent benefits. No significant differences were observed among the dextrose groups themselves.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with knee osteoarthritis (n=128).
effective_dosage: Intra-articular and periarticular injections of 5%, 10%, or 20% dextrose at weeks 0, 3, and 6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of dextrose prolotherapy in treating internal derangement of the temporomandibular joint.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, maximum mouth opening, clicking, and deviation at 2-, 4-, and 12-week intervals post-treatment, with pain reduction of 60% at 2 weeks and 200% at 4 weeks.
population_specificity: 20 patients with temporomandibular joint internal derangement confirmed by MRI.
effective_dosage: 12.5% dextrose injected into the posterior and anterior disc attachment and the most tender part of the masseter muscle.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 2, 4, and 12 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of hypertonic dextrose prolotherapy (HDPT) in managing temporomandibular joint internal derangement (TMJ-ID) symptoms, focusing on pain relief and joint function improvement.
results_summary: The study found that HDPT effectively reduced joint pain, improved maximum mouth opening (MMO), and achieved high patient satisfaction, with benefits lasting up to 12 months.
population_specificity: 286 patients with TMJ-ID (72% female, 28% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the treatment efficacy of subacromial steroid injections and dextrose prolotherapy for chronic subacromial bursitis patients.
results_summary: Dextrose prolotherapy provided short-term improvements in pain and disability at weeks 6 and 12, though steroid injections showed greater effectiveness in reducing pain and improving function at weeks 2, 6, and 12.
population_specificity: Fifty-four patients with chronic subacromial bursitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of medical dextrose tincture in treating facial photoaging compared to medical hyaluronic acid gel.
results_summary: Medical dextrose tincture significantly improved skin moisture, gloss, collagen density, and elasticity, with effects surpassing those of hyaluronic acid gel. Both subjective evaluations by doctors and volunteers confirmed noticeable improvements in skin photoaging.
population_specificity: 34 volunteers in a randomized double-blind study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mesotherapy administered three times at 28-day intervals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of intrauterine dextrose infusion on clinical metritis incidence, metabolic stress, systemic inflammation, and milk yield in postpartum dairy cows.
results_summary: Intrauterine dextrose infusion did not significantly reduce clinical metritis incidence and was associated with higher BHB and haptoglobin concentrations compared to untreated cows. CON cows produced more milk on certain days than DEX and SAL cows.
population_specificity: Clinically healthy postpartum dairy cows with normal vaginal discharge.
effective_dosage: 1 L of 50% dextrose solution (single intrauterine infusion).
study_duration: Single administration at 4 ± 1 days in milk, with follow-up assessments up to 21 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and electrophysiological improvements between perineural 5% dextrose injection therapy (5%PDIT) and perineural corticosteroid injection therapy (PCIT) in patients with mild-to-moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study found that 5%PDIT and PCIT showed similar therapeutic effects, with significant improvements in pain, symptom severity, and functional status at 1 and 6 months post-treatment. Electrophysiological improvements were also noted, particularly in median sensory nerve conduction velocity, with no significant differences between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with mild-to-moderate idiopathic carpal tunnel syndrome (92 wrists included).
effective_dosage: 5% dextrose solution (perineural injection, frequency not specified).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1 and 6 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether dextrose gel supplementation could reduce NICU admissions and intravenous dextrose therapy in asymptomatic hypoglycemic neonates.
results_summary: Dextrose gel supplementation significantly reduced NICU admissions (22% to 18.5%) and IV dextrose therapy (15.4% to 10.2%), while also improving breastfeeding rates (59.8% to 72.9%).
population_specificity: Asymptomatic hypoglycemic neonates, including those with high-risk characteristics (prematurity, large/small for gestational age, infants of diabetic mothers).
study_duration: Eight months before and after dextrose gel introduction

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intrathecal bupivacaine plus dextrose 5% and fentanyl versus bupivacaine alone on analgesia onset and duration in lower-limb orthopedic surgery patients.
results_summary: The intervention group (bupivacaine plus dextrose 5% and fentanyl) showed significantly lower VAS pain scores at 6 and 24 hours post-surgery and longer anesthesia duration compared to the control group (bupivacaine alone). Hemodynamic parameters were mixed, with some measures favoring the control group.
population_specificity: 40 patients undergoing lower-limb orthopedic surgery.
study_duration: Duration of spinal anesthesia administration (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of heavy bupivacaine-dextrose prolotherapy (HDP) for treating symptomatic chronic temporomandibular joint (TMJ) sub-luxation.
results_summary: The study found that HDP significantly reduced pain scores and improved maximum inter-incisal opening (MIO) without morphological changes or complications, demonstrating its effectiveness and safety for TMJ sub-luxation.
population_specificity: 60 patients diagnosed with chronic painful sub-luxation of the TMJ.
effective_dosage: Heavy bupivacaine-dextrose injection (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dextrose prolotherapy versus steroid injections in managing pain and functional outcomes in patients with tennis elbow.
results_summary: Both dextrose prolotherapy and steroid injections improved pain (VAS score) and function (MEPS score), but dextrose prolotherapy showed superior and longer-lasting results compared to steroid injections.
population_specificity: 260 patients with tennis elbow.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dextrose prolotherapy (DP) injections versus botulinum toxin type A (BTX-A) injections in reducing locking episodes and improving patient satisfaction in individuals with temporomandibular joint (TMJ) subluxation.
results_summary: The study found that dextrose prolotherapy significantly reduced locking episodes in TMJ subluxation patients, with no significant difference in efficacy compared to BTX-A injections. Patient satisfaction also showed no significant difference between the two treatment groups.
population_specificity: Adult patients with TMJ subluxation experiencing painful open-locking during wide mouth opening and/or yawning.
effective_dosage: Three sessions of dextrose injections around the TMJ (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments were conducted 8-12 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of 25% dextrose prolotherapy versus autologous blood prolotherapy in treating chronic recurrent temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dislocation.
results_summary: Dextrose prolotherapy was more effective than autologous blood in reducing pain intensity (VAS scale) but less effective in improving maximum mouth opening and mandibular movements. No significant difference was found in reducing dislocation frequency or TMJ sounds.
population_specificity: 20 patients with chronic recurrent TMJ dislocation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether dextrose administration during CPR improves resuscitation outcomes in patients with low blood sugar (<150 mg/dL) during cardiac arrest in the emergency department.
results_summary: Dextrose administration during CPR was not associated with improved outcomes, including return of spontaneous circulation, survival to hospital admission or discharge, or favorable neurological status. The study found no significant benefit or harm from dextrose use in this context.
population_specificity: Patients with intra-arrest blood glucose <150 mg/dL receiving CPR in the emergency department (mean age 59.5 ± 21.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dextrose prolotherapy (DPT) is an effective treatment for chronic ankle instability (CAI) compared to normal saline injections.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial to evaluate DPT's efficacy, but results are not yet available as the abstract only outlines the study design and hypotheses.
population_specificity: 114 patients with chronic ankle instability in Hong Kong.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of 5% dextrose perineural injection versus corticosteroid injection for treating mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: Both 5% dextrose and corticosteroid injections showed statistically significant improvements in pain (VAS), symptom severity (BCTQ-ss), and electrophysiological parameters, with no significant differences between the two treatments. The study concluded that 5% dextrose is an effective and safe alternative to corticosteroids for mild to moderate CTS.
population_specificity: 36 patients with mild to moderate CTS in one or both wrists.
effective_dosage: 2 cc of 5% dextrose perineural injection (single session).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1 month and 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dextrose gel treatment for neonatal hypoglycaemia affects long-term educational and neurodevelopmental outcomes at mid-childhood.
results_summary: Dextrose gel did not significantly impact low educational achievement but was associated with lower visual perception scores compared to placebo. Other neurodevelopmental outcomes were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Neonates with hypoglycaemia, followed up at 9-10 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of oral 10% dextrose with whole body massage therapy and Kangaroo care on pain scores during venipuncture in newborns.
results_summary: The study found that oral 10% dextrose had similar effects on pain scores during venipuncture as massage and Kangaroo care, with no significant differences in pain severity between the groups.
population_specificity: Newborns with gestational age ≥34 weeks in NICUs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effectiveness of 5% dextrose (D5W) injections against corticosteroids and platelet-rich plasma (PRP) for treating carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study found that D5W injections were moderately effective in relieving symptoms, improving function, and alleviating pain in CTS patients, ranking second after PRP but outperforming corticosteroids. The surface under the cumulative ranking curve for D5W was 74.4% for symptom relief, 72.2% for functional improvement, and 72.1% for pain alleviation.
population_specificity: Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome (749 patients, 817 hands).
effective_dosage: 5% dextrose water (D5W) injection (specific volume and frequency not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Short-term follow-up (exact duration not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of intraoperative cystoscopy distension using 5% dextrose in water (D5W) versus preoperative vitamin B2 for visualizing ureteric jets during pelvic reconstructive surgery.
results_summary: The study found that D5W was highly accurate (90.8%) for detecting ureteric jets but required more fluorescein rescue (11.8%) and had lower surgeon satisfaction compared to vitamin B2. No significant differences were observed in time to visualization, furosemide use, or postoperative urine culture results.
population_specificity: Adult women undergoing pelvic reconstructive surgery at three tertiary hospitals in Toronto, Canada.
effective_dosage: Bladder distension with 5% dextrose in water (D5W) intraoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of hypertonic dextrose versus corticosteroid injections on supraspinatus echogenicity and clinical outcomes in chronic supraspinatus tendinopathy.
results_summary: Hypertonic dextrose improved supraspinatus echogenicity at 6 weeks and provided short-term symptomatic relief, though steroid injections showed superior clinical improvements at 6 and 12 weeks. Dextrose's benefits were less pronounced but had no negative effects on tendon morphology.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic supraspinatus tendinopathy (n=75, 25 per group).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 2, 6, and 12 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 5% and 15% dextrose prolotherapy (PrT) on pain, functionality, and clinical improvement in chronic lateral epicondylitis, versus saline injections.
results_summary: Both 5% and 15% dextrose PrT were more effective than saline in improving pain, handgrip strength, functionality, and clinical outcomes, with 15% dextrose showing superior efficacy in handgrip strength, pressure-pain threshold, and early pain reduction. No significant differences in side effects or complications were noted between the dextrose groups.
population_specificity: 60 patients (aged 44.30±10.31 years) with chronic lateral epicondylitis.
effective_dosage: 5% dextrose (Group 1) and 15% dextrose (Group 2), administered as injections at weeks 0, 3, and 6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 0.45% and 0.9% saline in 5% dextrose on serum sodium levels and the incidence of hyponatremia in hospitalized children.
results_summary: The study found that 0.45% saline in 5% dextrose led to a significant drop in serum sodium levels and higher incidence of hyponatremia at 12 and 24 hours compared to 0.9% saline in 5% dextrose, though no significant difference was observed at 48 hours. Isotonic fluids (0.9% saline in 5% dextrose) were deemed more appropriate for hospitalized children.
population_specificity: Hospitalized children aged 3 months to 12 years requiring IV maintenance fluids.
effective_dosage: Standard maintenance rates of 0.45% or 0.9% saline in 5% dextrose.
study_duration: Up to 72 hours (primary outcome measured at 24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia with dextrose gel affects neurosensory impairment and other developmental outcomes at 2 years of age.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in neurosensory impairment between dextrose and placebo groups, but dextrose-treated children had worse visual processing scores and were taller and heavier. Secondary outcomes were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Neonates (>35 weeks gestation, <48 hours old) with hypoglycemia (<2.6 mmol/L).
study_duration: Single treatment at recruitment (follow-up at 2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the injection frequency of intra-articular dextrose prolotherapy needed to achieve a 50% improvement in pain (VAS score) and functional symptoms (WOMAC index) in patients with late-stage medial compartment knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Four out of six patients showed over 50% improvement in pain relief and functional outcomes after twelve sessions of dextrose prolotherapy, while two required additional doses due to insufficient progress. The combined therapy improved daily activity function and delayed the need for total knee arthroplasty.
population_specificity: Six patients with late-stage medial compartment knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Twelve sessions of intra-articular dextrose prolotherapy (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but involved twelve sessions (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dextrose-prolotherapy with other substances for pain relief in patients with primary knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Dextrose-prolotherapy showed improvements in pain relief compared to saline injections, but results were inconclusive when compared to other substances. The study could not definitively conclude whether dextrose-prolotherapy is superior or inferior to other treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with primary knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of ultrasound-guided dextrose prolotherapy versus corticosteroid injections for treating carpal tunnel syndrome.
results_summary: Dextrose prolotherapy showed similar efficacy to corticosteroid injections in improving pain intensity, functional limitations, electrophysiologic parameters, and ultrasonographic outcomes, with no significant differences observed over a 3-month follow-up period.
population_specificity: 54 patients with carpal tunnel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of hydrodissection with 5% dextrose for persistent or recurrent carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) after surgery.
results_summary: Nearly 61.1% of patients reported ≥50% symptom relief after a mean of 3.1 injections, with durable benefits observed over a mean follow-up of 33 months. Recurrent CTS cases showed significantly higher rates of excellent outcomes (>70% improvement) compared to persistent cases.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent or recurrent symptoms of CTS after primary surgery (n=36).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of perineural dextrose injections versus normal saline in treating ulnar neuropathy at the elbow.
results_summary: The dextrose group showed superior improvements in pain, disability, ulnar motor nerve velocity, and ulnar nerve cross-sectional area compared to the control group, particularly at weeks 4 and 12. The results were statistically significant (P<.001).
population_specificity: 40 patients with ulnar neuropathy at the elbow (20 in the dextrose group, 20 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 5% dextrose, 5 cc total (1 cc injected at five sites around the ulnar nerve), administered twice at 2-week intervals.
study_duration: 4 weeks (two injections at 2-week intervals), with follow-up until week 12.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the energy contribution of dextrose as a nonnutritive calorie source in ICU patients, particularly those receiving CRRT.
results_summary: Dextrose provided up to 992 kcal per ICU day, contributing significantly to nonnutritive calorie intake. Patients receiving CRRT had higher total energy intake, including from dextrose, compared to non-CRRT patients.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated patients admitted to medical-surgical ICUs.
effective_dosage: Not specified (energy contribution measured as 992 kcal per ICU day).
study_duration: Monitored over the first 7 days of ICU admission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dextrose gel could reduce the need for intravenous fluids in at-risk neonates with asymptomatic hypoglycemia.
results_summary: Dextrose gel significantly reduced treatment failure (11.5% vs. 40.2% in the control group) and the need for intravenous fluids across all studied categories (SGA/IUGR, IDM/LGA, and LPT neonates). The risk ratios were consistently favorable (0.28 overall).
population_specificity: At-risk neonates with asymptomatic hypoglycemia, stratified into SGA/IUGR, IDM/LGA, and LPT categories.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ingesting a 5% dextrose solution before gastroscopy affects gastric volume and patient comfort compared to fasting.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in gastric volume between the dextrose and fasting groups, but the dextrose group reported less discomfort and better gastric mucosal visualization. Blood glucose levels and adverse events were similar in both groups.
population_specificity: Elderly patients scheduled for elective gastroscopy.
effective_dosage: 5 ml/kg of 5% dextrose solution, ingested two hours before the procedure.
study_duration: Single administration two hours before gastroscopy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of extra-articular, neurofascial dextrose prolotherapy in treating chronic ankle ligament injury.
results_summary: The study found that dextrose prolotherapy significantly improved functional instability (measured by CAIT scores) and reduced pain (measured by VAS scores) in patients with chronic ankle ligament injury over six months.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic ankle ligament injury and functional instability (CAIT score < 25).
effective_dosage: 12.5% dextrose, two injections within one month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of various treatments, including dextrose, for managing nausea and vomiting in pregnancy (NVP) and hyperemesis gravidarum (HG).
results_summary: The study recommends thiamine supplementation before dextrose administration to prevent complications but does not provide specific safety or efficacy data for dextrose itself.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with NVP or HG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of resistance training with dextrose/maltodextrin supplementation compared to creatine supplementation in patients with breast cancer.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding dextrose's effects, as it focuses on the study design and intervention protocol rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as placebo in the same daily dosing protocol as creatine, 5 g/d)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic efficacy of 25% dextrose versus 24% sucrose for heel-lance pain relief in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that 25% dextrose was noninferior to 24% sucrose in reducing pain scores (PIPP) after heel-lance procedures, with no significant differences at 30, 60, or 120 seconds. Only one transient adverse event (coughing) was reported in the dextrose group.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (28–35 weeks gestation) admitted to the NICU.
effective_dosage: 0.5 mL of 25% dextrose, administered orally once before the procedure.
study_duration: Single administration, 2 minutes before the heel-lance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intra-articular co-injection of hypertonic dextrose with hyaluronic acid (HA) improves outcomes for knee osteoarthritis (OA) compared to HA plus normal saline.
results_summary: HA plus dextrose co-injections showed significant improvements in stair climbing time, physical function, pain reduction, and quality of life compared to HA plus saline, with benefits sustained up to 6 months. The treatment group also demonstrated better outcomes in walking speed, stiffness, and other symptoms.
population_specificity: 104 participants with knee OA (Kellgren-Lawrence score 2 or 3) in Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Once-weekly intra-articular injections for 3 weeks (exact dextrose concentration not specified).
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments up to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dextrose (as an energy-matched carbohydrate control) against β-lactoglobulin supplementation combined with resistance exercise on mitigating disuse-induced muscle atrophy.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results for dextrose, as it served as a placebo control. The primary focus was on β-lactoglobulin's impact on muscle protein synthesis, with dextrose used for energy matching rather than efficacy testing.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (18-45 years), both males and females.
effective_dosage: Energy-matched to 23 g of β-lactoglobulin, administered thrice daily.
study_duration: 7 days (prehabilitation period) followed by 5 days (immobilization period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing knowledge and uncertainties regarding nutritional aspects, including the role of dextrose, in patients undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that CRRT can lead to caloric gain from dextrose, but it does not provide specific findings on dextrose's effects, efficacy, or safety. The role of dextrose in this context remains unclear, highlighting the need for further research.
population_specificity: Patients with acute kidney injury receiving continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of inositol-stabilized arginine silicate (ASI) with dextrose on cognitive performance in young adults, comparing it to dextrose alone.
results_summary: The study found that ASI with dextrose significantly improved total RBANS and immediate memory scores compared to dextrose alone, but no other cognitive domains were assessed.
population_specificity: Young healthy adults (20.9 ± 3.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistance training combined with saffron supplementation versus resistance training with a dextrose placebo on markers of depression and happiness in untrained young males.
results_summary: The dextrose placebo group showed no significant changes in AEA, 2-AG, dopamine, or β-endorphin concentrations but did exhibit increased serotonin levels and happiness, though less than the saffron group. Both groups improved muscular endurance, with greater gains in the saffron group.
population_specificity: Untrained young males
effective_dosage: Not specified (dextrose pill used as placebo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of preoperative oral carbohydrate loading versus intravenous dextrose 10% infusion on postoperative pain, nausea, and quality of recovery in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
results_summary: Both oral carbohydrate and intravenous dextrose significantly reduced postoperative pain and nausea compared to the control group, with oral carbohydrate showing superior pain control in recovery. The quality of recovery was significantly higher in both intervention groups than in controls, with no significant differences in blood glucose levels.
population_specificity: 95 adult patients scheduled for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
effective_dosage: Intravenous dextrose 10% infusion (specific volume/frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers used dextrose as a placebo to compare the effects of nopal fiber supplementation on IBS symptoms.
results_summary: Dextrose (30 g/day) was used as a placebo and showed significantly lower symptom relief (33%) compared to nopal fiber doses (20 g/day: 87%, 30 g/day: 80%). No differences in breath hydrogen or stool SCFA were observed between dextrose and nopal fiber groups.
population_specificity: 60 patients meeting Rome IV criteria for IBS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether parenteral infusion of amino acids (AAs) during and after cardiac surgery could prevent hypoaminoacidemia caused by high-dose insulin therapy with dextrose titration.
results_summary: The study found that AA supplementation at 35% of resting energy expenditure (REE) effectively prevented hypoaminoacidemia, increasing essential and nonessential AAs post-surgery, while 20% REE supplementation did not. Dextrose was titrated to maintain normoglycemia but was not the primary focus of the study.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting surgery.
effective_dosage: Dextrose was titrated to maintain normoglycemia; specific dosage not provided.
study_duration: During and until 5 hours after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of oral sucrose-enriched breastmilk versus intravenous dextrose in treating hypoglycemia in small for gestational age neonates and assess risks of feed intolerance and necrotizing enterocolitis.
results_summary: Oral sucrose-enriched breastmilk maintained euglycemia comparably to intravenous dextrose, with no significant difference in recurrence of hypoglycemia, feed intolerance, or necrotizing enterocolitis. The method also prevented lactational failure.
population_specificity: Small for gestational age, hemodynamically stable hypoglycemic neonates (≥32 to ≤36 weeks gestational age).
effective_dosage: Similar calculated doses (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: Blood sugar measured at 6 hours post-treatment (intervention duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether amino acids with dextrose or dextrose alone affected postoperative complications and length of hospital stay in patients undergoing radical cystectomy for bladder cancer.
results_summary: The study found very uncertain evidence regarding whether amino acids with dextrose reduced postoperative complications or influenced hospital stay compared to dextrose alone, with very low-quality evidence due to serious limitations and imprecision.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing radical cystectomy for bladder cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 4 weeks of β-alanine supplementation improves performance metrics (e.g., sprint numbers, distance covered, time spent in speed zones) during a simulated water polo game.
results_summary: β-alanine supplementation significantly improved sprint numbers and had a likely beneficial effect on distance covered and time spent in high-speed zones during the game. No significant improvements were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 11 male water polo players

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of dextrose prolotherapy on clinical signs and symptoms in patients with disc displacement with reduction (DDWR).
results_summary: Dextrose injection significantly improved pain, maximal interincisal opening (MIO), and patient satisfaction compared to saline, with some improvement in joint sounds (JS) but no significant difference between groups.
population_specificity: Thirty patients suffering from bilateral DDWR.
effective_dosage: 25% dextrose solution, injected in two sites (superior joint space and retrodiscal tissue).
study_duration: Evaluated preoperatively, 1 week after each injection, and 3 and 6 months after the last injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the clinical efficacy and toxicity of Epigallocatechin Gallate (EGCG) in patients with AL amyloidosis.
results_summary: EGCG was well tolerated with no significant adverse events, and a decrease in urinary albumin levels was observed in patients with albuminuria, though its antioxidant activity may not fully explain its potential effects in AL amyloidosis.
population_specificity: Patients with AL amyloidosis (57 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of green tea catechins, particularly (-)-epigallocatechin gallate, on chronic diseases such as metabolic syndromes, cardiovascular diseases, neurodegenerative diseases, and cancer.
results_summary: The study highlights that (-)-epigallocatechin gallate shows potential in preventing and treating chronic diseases, with new insights into its molecular mechanisms. The effects are noted across multiple chronic conditions, though specific outcomes vary by disease.
population_specificity: Not specified (general chronic disease focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the acute psychoactive effects of EGCG, along with caffeine and L-theanine, on mood and cognitive performance based on existing human intervention studies.
results_summary: The study found no conclusive evidence regarding the effects of EGCG due to limited intervention studies. Previous research on caffeine and L-theanine showed clear benefits, but EGCG's impact remained undetermined.
population_specificity: Human intervention studies (general population, specifics not detailed).
